I. INTRODUCTION 
17 
Plaintiffs in this action are two recipients of federal benefits under the "Section 8 Housing Voucher 
18 
Program" (henceforth "S8HVP") pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o ) and a non-profit advocacy organization. 
19 
Defendants are the Housing Authority of the City of Los Angeles (henceforth "HACLA") and Rudolf 
20 
Montiel, the Executive Director ofHACLA. 
21 
In their First Amended Class Action Complaint (henceforth "FA  C"), Plaintiffs allege that: 
22 
2.  In or around July of2005, the Housing Authority of the City 
23  of Los Angeles ("HACLA"), which administers the Section 8 Program 
locally, began implementing a  large-scale rollback of housing benefits 
24  provided to Section 8 recipients in its jurisdiction. [ * * * *]. 
25  3.  Before  doing  so,  however,  HACLA  was  required  by 
applicable federal regulations, independently enforceable as well through 
26  state law, to provide adequate notice at least one year prior to the cut in the 
* * 
level of services. [  * *]. 
27 
4.  HACLA did not make any meaningful attempt to comply 
28  with this notice requirement.  Rather than separately providing a formal 
administrative notice informing Section 8 recipients that they would be 

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 63   Filed 11/26/07   Page 2 of 12   Page ID #:47
responsible for a specific increase in rent, HAC LA inserted into a large stack 
1  ofm  aterials sent to each recipient a nondescript and technically worded flyer 
that failed  to  convey any useful  information relating to the  change in 
2  benefits. 
3  See FAC at rs 2, 3 and 4.  Plaintiffs raise five causes of action:  I) "Denial of Due Process of Law (42 
4  U.S.C. ยง 1983)" for failing to provide notice to S8HVP recipients pursuant to 24 C.F.R. ยง 982.505(c)(3)(ii) 
5  before implementing the rollback of housing benefits which are a protected property interest under 42 
6  U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o); 2) "ViolationofRights Created by42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(Private Right of Action Available 
7  under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983)"; 3) "Violation of Cal. Gov't. Codeยง 815.6"; 4) "Violation of Art. I,ยง 7 of 
8  California Constitution"; and 5) "Negligence" pursuant to California Government Code ยง 815 .2, Civil Code 
9  ยง I 714 and Evidence Code ยง 669.1 Defendants now move to dismiss the second and fifth causes of action. 
10  II.  BACKGROUND 
11  A.  The S8HVP 
12  As noted in Cisneros v. Alpine Ridge Group. 508 U.S. 10, 12 (1993): 
13  In 1974, Congress amended the United States Housing Act of 1937 
(Housing Act) to create what is known as the Section 8 housing program. 
14  Through the Section 8 program,  Congress hoped to "ai[d]  low-income 
families in obtaining a decent place to live," 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(a) (1988 ed., 
15  Supp. III), by subsidizing private landlords who would rent to low-income 
tenants.  Under the program, tenants make rental payments based on their 
16  income  and  ability  to  pay;  the  Department  of Housing  and  Urban 
Development (HUD)  then makes "assistance payments" to  the  private 
17  landlords in an amount calculated to make up the difference between the 
tenant's contribution and a "contract rent" agreed upon by the landlord and 
18  HUD. 
19  One ofthe Section 8 programs is the S8HVP.  See 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o); 24 C.F.R. ยง 982.1(a)(l). 
20  The S8HVP is usually administered by a state or local governmental entity called a "public housing agency" 
21  or "PHA" within a designated geographic area.  See 24 C.F.R. ยง 982.l(a)(l).  HUD provides housing 
22  assistance funds to the PHAs and also supplies monies for the PHAs' administration of the programs.  Id . 
23 
24 
Plaintiffs' original Complaint contained two additional causes of action for "Violation of Cal. Civ. Codeยง 52.1" (which 
this Court dismissed without leave to amend) and "Taxpayers' ... Suit for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief under Cal. Code of 
25 
Civil Procedureยง 526a" (which Plaintiffs voluntarily withdrew). Also, this Court granted Defendants' initial Motion to Dismiss 
as to the second cause of action, but with leave to amend, because it found that count to be unclear as to the basis of the claim since 
26 
it appeared to be entirely duplicative of the first cause of action. Further, at the hearing on the Motion to Dismiss, the Court also 
heard Defendants' Motion to Strike Causes of Action Pursuant to California Code of Civil Procedure ยง 425.16.  In their papers 
27 
and at the oral argument, Plaintiffs conceded that their lawsuit did not challenge the decision to lower the S8HVP benefits but 
rather the Defendants' failure to give adequate notice to recipients prior to the effectuating the change.  See~. Reporter's 
28 
Transcript of April 30, 2007 hearing at page 12. 
2 

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 63   Filed 11/26/07   Page 3 of 12   Page ID #:48
HUD publishes the fair market rents (henceforth "FMR"? for designated geographic areas in the 
1 
United States.  See 24 C.F.R. ยงยง 888.111 and 982.503(a).  A public housing agency must adopt a payment 
2 
schedule that establishes "voucher payment standard amounts" (henceforth sometimes "VPSA") for each 
3 
FMR area within its jurisdiction. See 24 C.F.R. ยง 982.503(a). As to each FMR area, the PHA must set the 
4 
VPSA for each "unit size" where unit size is measured by the number of bedrooms (i.e., zero-bedroom or 
5 
studio, one-bedroom and so on).  Id.  The public housing agency is initially limited as to its choice of the 
6 
voucher payment standard amount.  As stated in 24 C.F.R. ยง 982.503(b)(l): 
7 
(i) The PHA may establish the payment standard amount for a unit 
8 
size at any level between 90 percent and II 0 percent of the published FMR 
for that unit size.  HUD approval is not required to establish a payment 
9 
standard amount in that range ("basic range"). 
(ii) The PHA may establish a separate payment standard amount 
10 
within the basic range for a designated part of an FMR area. 
11 
See also 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o)(l)(B). 
12 
The voucher payment standard amount is used to calculate the monthly housing assistance payment 
13 
for a family. See 24 C.F.R. ยง 982.505(a). Where the PHA has established a VPSA within the "basic range" 
14 
and where the rent for a family (including utilities except for telephone) for their particular unit falls within 
15 
that range, the amount of monthly assistance payment for that family will normally be: 
16 
... the amount by which the rent (including the amount allowed for tenant 
paid utilities) exceeds the greatest of the following amounts, rounded to the 
17 
nearest dollar: 
(i) 30 percent of the monthly adjusted income of the family. 
18 
(ii) 10 percent ofthe monthly income of the family. 
19 
42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o)(2)(A);3 see also 24 C.F.R. ยง 982.505(a). 
20 
Persons seeking S8HVP assistance must apply to the PHA and supply income and other information 
21 
to establish their eligibility to participate in the program.  See 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o)(4); 24 C.F.R. ยง 
22 
982.201(a) and (b).  Once in the program, the PHA must conduct, at a minimum, a yearly review of the 
23 
family income and other information of the S8HVP participants.  See 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o)(5); 24 C.F.R. 
24 
ยง 982.516(a). 
25 
26 
2  "Fair market rent means the rent, including the cost of utilities (except telephone}, as established by HUD ... for units 
of varying sizes (by number ofbedrooms), that must be paid in the market area to rent privately owned, existing, decent, safe and 
27 
sanitary rental housing of modest (non-luxury) nature with suitable amenities."  24 C.F.R. ยง 888.Jll(b). 
28 
"Adjusted income" is defined in 42 U.S. C. ยง 1437a(b)(5). 
3 

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 63   Filed 11/26/07   Page 4 of 12   Page ID #:49
As conceded by the Plaintiffs in their PAC, "PHAs have discretion to raise or lower the VPS[A] 
1 
within a statutorily prescribed range." SeePA  C at '1[26.  Under regulations promulgated by HUD, if a PHA 
2 
decreases the amounts on the payment standard schedule, "the lower payment standard amount generally 
3 
must be used to calculate the monthly housing assistance payment for the family beginning at the effective 
4 
date of the family's second regular reexamination following the effective date of the decrease in the 
5 
payment standard amount."  24 C.P.R. ยง 982.505(c)(3).  There is a three step process. 
6 
Decrease  in  the  payment standard amount during  the  HAP  [housing 
7 
assistance payments] contract term.  If the amount on the payment standard 
schedule is decreased during the term of the  HAP contract, the lower 
8 
payment standard amount generally must be used to calculate the monthly 
housing assistance payment for the family beginning at the effective date of 
9 
the family's second regular reexamination following the effective date oft he 
decrease in the payment standard amount.  The PHA must determine the 
10 
payment standard for the family as follows. 
11 
(i) Step I: At the first regular reexamination following the decrease in the 
payment standard amount, the PHA shall determine the payment standard 
12 
for the family[ ... ] (using the decreased payment standard amount). 
13 
(ii) Step 2 (first reexamination payment standard amount): The PHA shall 
compare the payment standard amount from step I to the payment standard 
14 
amount last used to calculate the monthly housing assistance payment for the 
family.  The payment standard amount used by the PHA to calculate the 
15 
monthly housing assistance payment at  the  first  regular reexamination 
following the decrease in the payment standard amount is the higher oft hese 
16 
two payment standard amounts.  The PHA shall advise the family that the 
application of the lower payment standard amount will be deferred until the 
17 
second regular reexamination following the effective date oft he decrease in 
the payment standard amount. 
18 
(iii) Step 3 (second reexamination payment standard amount): At the second 
19 
regular reexamination following  the decrease  in the  payment  standard 
amount, the lower payment standard amount shall be used to calculate the 
20 
monthly housing assistance payment for the family unless the PHA has 
subsequently increased the payment standard amount .... 
21 
24 C.P.R. ยง 982.505(c)(3)(i) thru (iii) [emphasis added]. 
22 
As stated in 24 C.P.R.ยง 982.5: "Where part 982 requires any notice to be given by the PHA, the 
23 
family or the owner, the notice must be in writing." 
24 
B.  Operative Allegations 
25 
In regards to the HACLA's purported failure to provide notice to the Plaintiff class, the operative 
26 
allegations are contained in paragraphs 28 through 31 of the PAC which state: 
27 
28.  On April2, 2004, HAC LA made a decision to reduce the pre-
28 
4 

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 63   Filed 11/26/07   Page 5 of 12   Page ID #:50
existing VPS. The impact on Section 8 participants was significant.  For 
1 
example, the VPS for a 0-bedroom ("bachelor") apartment plummeted from 
$795 to $674, a reduction of$121 per month. 
2 
29.  To implement this change in policy, the HAC LA stuck a one-
3 
page flyer in the materials mailed to each recipient on the date of their 
annual re-examination. Unlike other explanatory notices contained in these 
4 
packets, the flyer did not require the recipient to acknowledge receipt by 
signing and returning the form.  The flyer was not on letterhead, did not 
5 
contain a phone number for inquiries, and did not give a legal basis for the 
decision. More importantly, the flyer did not advise recipients that their out 
6 
of-pocket rent payment would actually be going up, much less specifY the 
amount of the increase.  Plaintiffs are informed and believe, and on that 
7 
basis  allege,  that  these  flyers  were  sent  out,  buried  among  other 
reexamination materials, from approximately July 2004 through July 2005. 
8 
30.  The language oft he flyer did not meaningfully communicate 
9 
to the recipient that there would actually be a reduction in the portion of his 
or her rent that HACLA would pay, and a corresponding increase in the 
10 
portion of his or her rent that the recipient would be required to pay. 
11 
31.  The VPS decrease went into effect with re-examinations that 
took place from July 2005 to July 2006. 
12 
See FAC at rs 28 through 31. 
13 
Plaintiffs' first cause of action is a 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 claim of a denial of due process against 
14 
Defendant HACLA.  They contend that they have "a property interest in the provisions of [24] C.F.R. ยง 
15 
16  982.505(c)(3)(ii) under both state and federal law ...."   See FAC at~ 58.  In paragraph 59 of the FAC, 
Plaintiffs assert that: 
17 
By failing to provide Plaintiff Class clear or meaningful notice oft he actions 
18 
HACLA intended to take and its consequences at the time required by 24 
C.F.R. 982.505(c)(3)(ii), most particularly by failing to meaningfully or 
19 
effectively advise the Plaintiff Class that their out of pocket share of future 
rents would be increased [ ... ] and by failing to indicate from whom the 
20 
notice emanated, the legal basis for the action, a phone number for inquiries, 
or how to protest or appeal the action, Defendant HACLA deprived the 
21 
Plaintiff Class  of due  process  of law  in  violation  of the  Fourteenth 
Amendment,  thereby entitling the  Class  to  bring the  suit  and  recover 
22 
damages pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983. 
23 
Plaintiffs seek "injunctive and declaratory relief, an accounting, restitution and/or damages."  Id.  61. 
at~ 
24 
Plaintiffs' second cause of action seeks to establish a claim based upon a purported violation of 
25 
rights created by 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o) which allegedly can be litigated through a "private right of action 
26 
available under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983."  See FA  C at page 17.  As stated in paragraphs 68 and 69 of the FAC: 
27 
68.  In sum, 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o)(2) and the other sections cited 
above required HACLA to  make  monthly payments for the benefit of 
28 
5 

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 63   Filed 11/26/07   Page 6 of 12   Page ID #:51
recipients  according to  the "applicable  payment  standard."  That  is  a 
1 
federally secured right.  The regulations flush [sic]  out how HACLA's 
monthly payments are to be calculated by specifYing how the applicable 
2 
payment standard is to be determined.  By failing to provide the required 
notice, the new payment standard implemented by HACLA was unlawful. 
3 
HAC LA, therefore, violated 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o ) (2) by failing to make the 
required payments under the "applicable payment standard." 
4 
69.  Defendants,  as  described  in  this  complaint,  deprived 
5 
Plaintiffs and the Plaintiff Class of their federal rights, specifically their 
voucher payment standard rights created by 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f( o) , including 
6 
ยง 1437(o)(2) andยง 1437f(o)(l), under the color of state law, and thereby 
violated 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983. 
7 
II.  DISCUSSION 
8 
A.  Applicable Law 
9 
Defendants herein seek to dismiss the second and fifth causes of action pursuant to Federal Rules 
10 
of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).  As stated in Balistreri v. Pacifica Police Dept., 901 F.2d 696, 699 (9th Cir. 
11 
1990). 
12 
A complaint should not be dismissed under Rule 12(b )( 6) "unless it appears 
13 
beyond doubt that the plaintiff can prove no set of facts in support of his 
claim which would entitle him to relief."  Conley v. Gibson, 355 U.S. 41, 
14 
45-46 (1957).  Dismissal can be based on lack of cognizable legal theory or 
the absence of sufficient facts  alleged under a cognizable legal theory. 
15 
Robertson v. Dean Witter Reynolds. Inc., 749 F.2d 530, 533-34 (9th Cir. 
1984).  On a motion to dismiss, the court accepts the facts alleged in the 
16 
complaint as true.  Shah, 797 F.2d at 745. 
17 
B.  Plaintiffs' Second Cause of Action 
18 
Before considering the viability of the Plaintiffs' Second Cause of Action (henceforth "SCA"), it 
19 
should initially be noted that Defendants have not moved to dismiss the First Cause of Action (henceforth 
20 
"FCA") which asserts that HACLA violated 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 by denying Plaintiffs due process in failing 
21 
to give them sufficient notice as required by 24 C.F.R. ยง 982.505(c  )(3)(ii) before reducing S8HVP benefits. 
22 
Likewise, Plaintiffs have conceded that PHAs (such as HACLA) have the discretion to lower the voucher 
23 
program standard amount (which is used to calculate the S8HVP benefits) within certain limitations. 
24 
Plaintiffs have not (and apparently do not) contend that HACLA acted substantively or procedurally in an 
25 
unlawful manner in deciding to reduce the S8HVP benefits, except as to the notice issue.  In light of the 
26 
above, Plaintiffs' SCA either : 1) is simply the same claim as the FCA but stated in slightly different words, 
27 
or 2) fails to state a cognizable legal theory other than a due process claim based on lack of notice and fails 
28 
6 

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 63   Filed 11/26/07   Page 7 of 12   Page ID #:52
to allege sufficient facts that would establish a cognizable legal theory under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983. 
1 
Plaintiffs' SCA is based on the following syllogism: I) the S8VHP benefits are "a federally secured 
2 
right"; 2) HUD regulations flesh out how HACLA's monthly payments are to be calculated; 3) by failing 
3 
to provide the required notice, HACLA's reduction in S8HVP benefits is unlawful and 4) "HACLA, 
4 
therefore, violated 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f( o) (2) by failing to make the required payments under the 'applicable 
5 
payment standard'" which constitutes a violation of 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983.  See FAC at ~'s 68-69.  Plaintiffs' 
6 
SCA fails to state a claim for the reasons stated below. 
7 
As held in Wright v. Roanoke Redevelopment & Housing Authoritv, 479 U.S. 418,423 (1987), 42 
8 
U.S.C. ยง 1983 is available to enforce violations of federal statutes by agents of a state with two exceptions: 
9 
where Congress has foreclosed such enforcement and where the statute did not create enforceable rights 
10 
within the meaning ofยง 1983.  The Court stated, as to the first exception, that "we conclude that nothing 
11 
in the Housing Act ... evidences that Congress intended to preclude ... [a] ยง 1983 claim against [a PHA]." 
12 
Id. at 429.  In regards to the second exception, the Supreme Court has retreated from its position in Wright 
13 
that spending legislation automatically gives rise to enforceable rights underยง 1983.  As delineated in 
14 
Gonzaga Universitv v. Doe, 536 U.S. 273, 281 (2002): "Our more recent decisions, however, have rejected 
15 
attempts to infer rights from Spending Clause statutes."  The Court went on to state: 
16 
We now reject the notion that our cases permit anything short of an 
17 
unambiguously conferred right to support a cause of action brought under 
ยง 1983. Section 1983 provides a remedy only for the deprivation of"rights, 
18 
privileges, or immunities secured by the Constitution and laws" of the 
United States. Accordingly, it is rights, not the broader or vaguer "benefits" 
19 
or "interests," that may be enforced under the authority of that section. This 
being so, we further reject the notion that our implied right of action cases 
20 
are separate and distinct from ourยง 1983 cases. To the contrary, our implied 
right of action cases should guide the determination of whether a statute 
21 
confers rights enforceable underยง 1983. 
22 
We have  recognized that  whether a statutory violation may be 
enforced through  ยง  1983  "is a  different inquiry than that involved  in 
23 
determining whether a  private  right of action  can be  implied  from  a 
particular statute."  Wilder. supra, 496 U.S. 498 at 508, n.  9.  But the 
24 
inquiries overlap in one meaningful respect -- in either case we must first 
determine whether Congress intended to create a federal right.  Thus, we 
25 
have held that "the question whether Congress . . . intended to create a 
private right of action [is] definitively answered in the negative" where "a 
26 
statute by  its terms grants  no  private rights to  any identifiable class." 
Touche Ross & Co. v. Redington, 442 U.S. 560, 576 (1979).  For a statute 
27 
to create such private rights, its text must be "phrased in terms oft he persons 
benefitted."  Cannon v. University of Chicago, 441 U.S. 677, 692, n.  13 
28 
7 

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 63   Filed 11/26/07   Page 8 of 12   Page ID #:53
(1979). * * * * But even where a statute is phrased in such explicit rights 
1 
creating terms, a plaintiff suing under an implied right of action still must 
show that the statute manifests an intent "to create not just a private right but 
2 
also a private remedy."  Alexander v. Sandoval, 532 U.S. 275,286 (2001) 
(emphases added). 
3 
See also Hill v. Richardson, 7 F.3d 656,658 (7th Cir. 1993) ("Wright was closely divided, and Suter [v. 
4 
Artist M, 503 U.S. 347 (1992)] shows that the Court is unwilling to press Wright for the most it can be 
5 
worth."). 
6 
In this case, Plaintiffs are not claiming that the HACLA's decision to reduce voucher payment 
7 
standard amounts was unlawful, improper or beyond its authority. Thus, while S8HVPs may be a federally 
8 
secured right, HACLA's reduction of the VPSA has not violated that right.  Rather, Plaintiffs' actual 
9 
complaint is as to a purported failure by HACLA to give adequate notice before effectuating the reduction. 
10 
While such failure of notice may give rise to a due process complaint that could in turn give rise to aยง 1983 
11 
claim (which is, in essence, the substance of Plaintiffs' FCA),4 inadequate notice by itself is not otherwise 
12 
cognizable as a ยง 1983 deprivation of rights claim. 
13 
First, the applicable federal statute does not require any notice to be given before a PHA reduces 
14 
the VPSA so long as the reduction is not Jess than 90 percent of the FMR published by HUD for the 
15 
designated geographic area within the PHA'sjurisdiction.  See 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o).  Therefore, even if 
16 
HACLA's notice in this case was inadequate, such conduct would not violate a federal statute so as to give 
17 
rise to aยง 1983 claim under the previously established (but now questioned) holding in Wright thatยง 1983 
18 
is available to enforce violations of federal statutes by agents of a State. 
19 
Second, Plaintiffs cite to HUD's regulation at 24 C.P.R. ยง 982.505(c)(3) for the existence of such 
20 
notice requirement and then argue that the failure to comply with that regulation gives rise to the ยง 1983 
21 
claim.  That contention must fail in light of the decision in Alexander v. Sandoval, 532 U.S. 275 (2001). 
22 
In Alexander, the Supreme Court rejected the argument that, where a regulation contains some "rights-
23 
creating language," the regulation can provide a basis for private enforcement under ยง 1983 that goes 
24 
beyond what the statute itself requires.  Id. at 291 and 293 fnt. 8.  As stated by the Court: 
25 
Language in a regulation may invoke a private right of action that Congress 
26 
27 
For purposes of deciding this motion, this Court need not and does not reach a decision as to whether a failure to give 
28 
adequate notice would constitute a due process violation which can be litigated as a ยง 1983 claim in this case. 
8 

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 63   Filed 11/26/07   Page 9 of 12   Page ID #:54
through statutory text created, but it may not create a right that Congress has 
1 
not.  Touche Ross &  Co.  v.  Redington, 442 U.S., at 577 n.  18  ("[T]he 
language of the statute and not the rules must control").  Thus, when a 
2 
statute has  provided a general authorization for  private enforcement of 
regulations, it may perhaps be correct that the intent displayed in each 
3 
regulation can determine whether or not it is privately enforceable. But it is 
most certainly incorrect to say that language in a regulation can conjure up 
4 
a private cause of action that has not been authorized by Congress. Agencies 
may play the sorcerer's apprentice but not the sorcerer himself. 
5 
Id. at 291.  See also Save Our Valley v. Sound Transit, 335 F.3d at 932, 936-940 (9th Cir. 2003). 
6 
Plaintiffs' reliance on the Wright decision and Johnson v. Housing Authoritv of Jefferson Parish, 
7 
442 F.3d 356 (5th Cir.), cert. denied, 127 S.Ct.  136 (2006), is unavailing.  In both of those cases, the 
8 
disputes revolved around the allocation of utilities expenses; in Wright it was a claim of over-billing for 
9 
utilities by the defendant City Housing Authority (see 479 U.S. at 419), and in Johnson it was the failure 
10 
of the defendant PHA to use current rates in calculating the utility allowance (see 442 F.3d at 359).  As 
11 
explained in Johnson: 
12 
... the statutory language of the voucher program unmistakably provides- 
13 
in the text of the act itself-- for an "amount [to be] allowed for tenant paid 
utilities."  [42  U.S.C.  ยง  1437f(o)(2)(A),  (B).]  Contrary to  the  Housing 
14 
Authority's assertion, the HUD regulations are not necessary to establish 
Plaintiff-Appellants' right to the utility allowance, and certainly no more so 
15 
than they were in Wright, where such an allowance was not even mentioned 
in the text of the  statute itself.  Congress's intent to benefit Plaintiffs 
16 
Appellants here cannot be gainsaid. 
17 
Id. at 364 (footnote omitted).  In both Wright and Johnson, the claims were based on the statutory right to 
18 
receive the correct amount of rent assistance payments as delineated in the Housing Act as amended. Here, 
19 
unlike the Wright and Johnson cases, Plaintiffs are not challenging the PHA's calculation as to the amount 
20 
of the assistance as set forth in the statute.  Rather, they are raising an issue of adequacy of notice which 
21 
is not required in the applicable statute but only in the regulation. Thus, the Wright and Johnson decisions 
22 
are inapplicable, while the holdings in Alexander and Save Our Valley are controlling. 
23 
Moreover, even assuming arguendo that a violation of a notice provision in a regulation (that is not 
24 
required by the underlying statute) can serve theoretically as a basis for a ยง 1983 action, Plaintiffs would 
25 
still not have stated a cognizable claim for two reasons. First, HAC LA has not violated the notice provision 
26 
as set out in the regulation.  Second, if the notice provision requires more than what HACLA provided, it 
27 
is too vague and amorphous to confer an enforceable right. 
28 
9 

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 63   Filed 11/26/07   Page 10 of 12   Page ID #:55
Plaintiffs claim that the notice provided by HAC LA was inadequate because it: 1) did not require 
1 
the recipient to acknowledge receipt by signing and returning the form; 2) was not on HACLA letterhead; 
2 
3) did not contain a phone number for inquiries; 4) did not state a legal basis for the decision; and 5) did 
3 
not advise the recipient of how much their out of pocket rent payments would increase.  See FAC rs 29 
4 
and 59. However, the only regulation cited by Plaintiffs does not state that any of those items are required. 
5 
24 C.F.R. ยง 982.505(c)(3)(ii) merely provides that, after a PHA has calculated the appropriate payment 
6 
standard amount at the first yearly reexamination following the decrease in the VPSA, "the PHA shall 
7 
advise the family that the application of the lower payment standard amount will be deferred until the 
8 
second regular reexamination following the effective date oft he decrease in the payment standard amount." 
9 
It makes no reference to having the recipient acknowledge receipt, letterhead, phone numbers, explanation 
10 
of the legal basis for its decision, etc. 
11 
Plaintiffs have not alleged that HACLA failed in fact to give the only advisal that is required by the 
12 
language of24 C.F.R. ยง 982.505(c)(3)(ii). Moreover, 24 C.F.R. ยง 982.5 which sets out the only condition 
13 
for notice merely states that "Where Part 982 requires any notice to be given by the PHA ... , the notice 
14 
must be in writing."  Here, Plaintiffs in paragraph 4 of the FAC indicate that HACLA did give written 
15 
notice. 
16 
It is further noted that where specific information is required to be given to a S8HVP participant, 
17 
18  the HUD regulation will set forth these requirements.  See,~. 24 C.F.R. ยงยง 982.301(b) and 982.554(a). 
Likewise, where a participant can challenge the PHA decision, the PHA must give that participant notice 
19 
of the availability of an informal hearing.  However, a PHA's decision setting the VPSA within the basic 
20 
range is not subject to informal hearings.  24 C.F.R. ยง 982.555. 
21 
Finally, in order for a court to conclude that a statute creates a right enforceable underยง 1983, it 
22 
must find:  I) the statute was intended to benefit the plaintiffs; 2) the statute imposes a binding obligation 
23 
on the government unit rather than merely expressing a congressional preference for a certain kind of 
24 
conduct, and 3) the interest asserted by the plaintiff is not so vague and amorphous that it is beyond the 
25 
26  competence of the judiciary to enforce.  See Wilder v. Virginia Hosp. Asin., 496 U.S. 498,509 (1990); 
Legal Services ofNorthem Calif. v. Arnett, 114 F.3d 135, 138 (9th Cir. 1997).  Here, as noted above, the 
27 
statute does not impose any obligation (let alone a binding one) in regards to notice.  Even if one were to 
28 
10 

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 63   Filed 11/26/07   Page 11 of 12   Page ID #:56
utilize the referenced regulation as an appropriate surrogate for a statute, 24 C.F.R. ยง 982.505(c )(3)(ii) does 
1 
not set out any binding obligation insofar as the procedural requirements which Plaintiffs seek to impose 
2 
3  (~,acknowledgment ofr eceipt ofn otice, explanation oflegal basis, telephone numbers, etc.). Moreover, 
aside from the due process claim which is the subject of the FCA, the interest asserted by Plaintiffs in the 
4 
SCA is so vague and amorphous that it fails to confer on SSHVP participants an enforceable "right" within 
5 
the meaning ofยง 1983. 
6 
For all of the above reasons, the SCA is dismissed with prejudice. 
7 
C.  Plaintiffs' Fifth Cause of Action 
8 
Plaintiffs' fifth cause of action is for negligence based on California Government Code ยง 815 .2, 
9 
Evidence Codeยง 669, and Civil C?de ยง 1714.  None of those provisions provides a basis for Plaintiffs' 
10 
negligence claim. 
11 
As stated in Eastburn v. Regional Fire Protection Agency, 31 Cal. 4th 1175, 1179 (2003): 
12 
... the California Tom Claims Act provides that "[a] public entity is not 
13 
liable for an injury," "[e]xcept as otherwise provided by statute."  (Gov. 
Code,ยง 815; subd. (a).)  As that language indicates, the intent of the Tort 
14 
Claims Act is to confine potential governmental liability, not expand it. 
(Zelig v. Countv of Los Angeles (2002) 27 Cal.4th 1112, 1127. 
15 
Civil Code ยง 1714(a) states that "Every one is responsible ... for an injury occasioned by his want of 
16 
ordinary care of skill in the management of his property or person ...."   Eastburn held that the ordinary 
17 
negligence liability provision in Civil Code ยง 1714 is inapplicable to public entities. As stated in Eastburn, 
18 
31 Ca1.4th at 1183: 
19 
In other words, direct tort liability of public entities must be based on a 
20 
specific statute declaring them to be liable, or at least creating some specific 
duty of care, and not on the general tort provisions of Civil Code section 
21 
1714.  Otherwise, the general rule of immunity for public entities would be 
largely eroded by the routine application of general tort principles. 
22 
Government Code ยง 815.2(a) provides that: "A public entity is liable for injury proximately caused 
23 
by an act or omission of an employee of the public entity within the scope of his employment if the act or 
24 
omission would, apart from this section, have given rise to a cause of action against that employee or his 
25 
26  personal representative [emphases added]."  ยง 815.2(a) does not provide a basis for a common law claim 
for negligence against a public entity for its own negligent conduct.  As stated in Zelig v. Countv of Los 
27 
Angeles, 27 Ca1.4th 1112, 1127 (2002): 
28 
11 

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 63   Filed 11/26/07   Page 12 of 12   Page ID #:57
The Tort Claims Act draws a clear distinction between the liability of a 
1 
public entity based on its own conduct, and the liability arising from the 
conduct of a public employee.  Although the Act provides that a public 
2 
employee generally is  liable for  an injury caused by  his  or her act or 
omission "to the same extent as a private person" (Gov. Code.,ยง 820, subd. 
3 
(a)) and that, when the act or omission of the public employee occurs in the 
scope of employment the public entity will be vicariously liable for the 
4 
injury  (Gov.  Code  ยง  815.2),  the  Act  contains  no  provision  similarly 
providing that a public entity generally is liable for its own conduct or 
5 
omission to the same extent as a private person or entity.  Rather, the Act 
provides that a public entity is not liable for an injury"[ e ]xcept as otherwise 
6 
provided by statute ...."   (Gov. Code,ยง 815.) 
7 
Evidence Codeยง 669(a) provides that a "failure of a person to exercise ordinary case is presumed 
8 
if:  (1) he violated a statute, ordinance, or regulation of a public entity ...."   However, as noted in 
9  California Service Station etc. Assn. v. American Home Assurance Co., 62 Cal.App.4th 1166, 1177-78 
10 
(1998), a claim of ordinary negligence must be viable before the presumption of negligence in Evidence 
11 
Codeยง 669(a) can be employed.  The mere fact that a person has violated a statute or regulation does not, 
12 
by itself, establish that the result will be the tort of negligence.  Id. at 1178-79.  Plaintiffs have offered 
13 
nothing to suggest that a purported failure to provide adequate notice under 24 C.F.R. ยง 982.505( c) (3)(ii) 
14 
should be treated as negligence.  Moreover, as discussed above, Plaintiffs' allegations in the FA  C do not 
15 
set forth a basis for finding that HACLA has violated the notice requirement ofยง 982.505(c)(3)(ii).  That 
16 
regulation does not delineate any duty or standard of care as to how the advisal is to be given. To the extent 
17 
that the HUD regulations in 24 C.F .R. Part 982 can be said to forth a duty of care regarding notice, as 
18 
discussed above, HACLA has complied with it. 
19 
IV.  CONCLUSION 
20 
For the reasons stated above and at the hearings on Defendants' Motion to Dismiss, the second and 
21 
fifth causes of action in the FA  C are hereby dismissed with prejudice.

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA
CIVIL MINUTES - GENERAL
Case No. CV 07-380 PA (FFMx) Date February 15, 2018
Title Michael Nozzi, et al. v. Housing Authority for the City of Los Angeles, et al.
Present: The Honorable PERCY ANDERSON, UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE
Kamilla Sali-Suleyman  Not Reported N/A
Deputy Clerk Court Reporter Tape No.
Attorneys Present for Plaintiffs: Attorneys Present for Defendants:
None None
Proceedings:  MOTIONS FOR FINAL APPROVAL OF CLASS ACTION SETTLEMENT
AND ATTORNEYSโ FEES
Before the Court are a Motion for Final Approval of Class Action Settlement (Docket No. 322)
and a Motion for Attorneysโ Fees and Costs (Docket No. 307) filed by plaintiffs Michael Nozzi
(โNozziโ) and Nidia Pelaez (โPelaezโ) (collectively โPlaintiffsโ or โNamed Plaintiffsโ).  Defendants
Housing Authority of the City of Los Angeles (โHACLAโ) and Rudolph Montiel in his official capacity1/
(collectively โDefendantsโ) do not oppose either motion.  A Fairness Hearing was held on January 29,
2018.
I.  FACTUAL & PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The Section 8 housing program provides rental assistance to low-income, elderly, and disabled
families.  See Nozzi v. HACLA, 806 F.3d 1178, 1184 (9th Cir. 2015) (โNozzi IIโ).  The majority of this
assistance is provided through the Housing Choice Voucher Program, which is funded and regulated by
the Department of Housing and Urban Development (โHUDโ) and administered locally by public
housing agencies such as HACLA.  Id.  Under this program, the renter identifies qualifying housing, the
public housing agency negotiates the rent with the landlord, the public housing agency pays a rent
subsidy to the landlord on behalf of the tenant, and the renter pays the balance of the rent.  Id.  Within
parameters established by HUD, the public housing agency sets a voucher payment standard (VPS)
representing the maximum subsidy that it will pay for each type of housing in a particular area.  Id. at
1185.  Raising the VPS will generally yield larger subsidies, while lowering the VPS will generally yield
smaller subsidies.  Id.  Each renterโs eligibility for Section 8 benefits is examined on a yearly basis.  Id. 
โIf the public housing agency decides to lower the [VPS], it must provide information about the change
to all beneficiaries at their annual reexaminations following the decision, and must further advise these
beneficiaries that the change will not go into effect until their following reexamination one year later.โ 
Id.
1/ The City of Los Angeles was originally named as a defendant, but was dismissed on May 23,
2007.  (Docket No. 48.)
CV-90 (06/04) CIVIL MINUTES - GENERAL Page 1 of 12

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 331   Filed 02/15/18   Page 2 of 12   Page ID #:5961
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA
CIVIL MINUTES - GENERAL
Case No. CV 07-380 PA (FFMx) Date February 15, 2018
Title Michael Nozzi, et al. v. Housing Authority for the City of Los Angeles, et al.
HACLA reduced its VPS in 2004.  Under the new standard, an estimated 45% of tenants were
required to pay an average of $104 more in rent each month.  Id. at 1186.  HACLA notified renters of
this change in a flyer sent with annual reexamination documents.  Id.  The flyer provided general
information about the new VPS, but did not specify how the changes would affect each renter.  Id.  An
individualized notice was not provided until a second notice sent approximately four weeks before the
new subsidy would take effect for each renter.  Id.
Plaintiffs, along with the now-defunct Los Angeles Coalition to End Hunger & Homelessness,
initiated this action in January 2007.  Id.  In April 2007, the district court granted in part and denied in
part a motion to dismiss.  (Docket No. 42.)  Plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint alleging
violations of (1) due process of law under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, (2) rights created by 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f,
(3) Cal. Gov. Code ยง 815.6, (4) Art. I, ยง 7 of the California Constitution, and (5) negligence.  (Docket
No. 49.)  The Court dismissed the second and fifth claims (Docket No. 63) and later granted Defendantsโ
motion for summary judgment on the remaining claims (Docket No. 90).  The Ninth Circuit reversed the
dismissal of the fifth claim and the grant of summary judgment on the first, third, and fourth claims. 
Nozzi v. HACLA, No. 09โ55588, 2011 WL 1167188 (9th Cir. 2011) (โNozzi Iโ).  On remand, the
district court granted HACLAโs renewed motion for summary judgment.  (Docket Nos. 190, 192.)  The
Ninth Circuit again reversed, holding that the flyer sent by HACLA did not provide sufficient notice of
the VPS change.  The court found that this โfailure violated both the requirements of the Voucher
Program regulations and the requirements of procedural due process,โ as well as state law.  Nozzi II, 806
F.3d at 1204.  The matter was remanded โwith instructions for the district court to enter summary
judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on the merits of the federal and state law claims at issue on this
appeal.โ  Id.  
Following remand, this Court certified two classes: (1) the Rule 23(b)(2) โInjunctive Relief
Classโ and (2) the Rule 23(b)(3) โDamages Class.โ  (Docket No. 245.)  The Injunctive Relief Class
consists of all Section 8 beneficiaries whose benefits are administered by HACLA and who in the past
received, or in the future may receive, notices of a VPS decrease.  (Id.)  The Damages Class consists of
all HACLA Section 8 tenants, between June 1, 2005, and September 30, 2006, whose rental contribution
for a period not to exceed eleven months was greater than it would have been but for HACLAโs 2004
decrease in the VPS.  (Id.)  All Damages Class Members are also members of the Injunctive Relief
Class.  (Docket No. 297, Ex. A (โSettlement Agreementโ) ยถ 7.)  The Damages Class consists of 11,870
tenants on the Damages Class Member List, and their principal damages amount to $10,308,774.  (See
id. ยถยถ 9, 10; Docket No. 297, Ex. D ยถ 3.)  
In February 2017, the parties filed cross-motions for partial summary judgment as to remedies. 
(Docket Nos. 250, 256.)  Before the Court ruled on those motions, the parties filed a Stipulation for
Settlement.  (Docket No. 286.)  On June 19, 2017, Plaintiffs filed an unopposed Motion for Preliminary
Approval of Class Action Settlement.  (Docket No. 296.)  On July 29, 2017, the Court preliminarily
approved the Settlement Agreement, as well as the appointment of JND Legal Administration (โJNDโ)
as Class Administrator, and Barrett S. Litt, Anne Richardson, and Stephanie Carroll as Class Counsel. 
(Docket No. 305 (โPrelim. Approval Orderโ).)

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA
CIVIL MINUTES - GENERAL
Case No. CV 07-380 PA (FFMx) Date February 15, 2018
Title Michael Nozzi, et al. v. Housing Authority for the City of Los Angeles, et al.
Plaintiffs now move for final approval of the Settlement Agreement.  In addition, Plaintiffs seek
approval of attorneysโ fees, litigation costs, settlement administration costs, and incentive awards.
II. THE SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT
The Settlement Agreement was reached after ten years of litigation, two appeals, and two days of
mediation before a retired federal judge. (See Settlement Agreement pp. 2โ3.)  The parties ultimately
agreed that HACLAโs insurers would pay a total of between $9 million and $9.4 million toward the
โClass Fundโ to settle all monetary claims of the Damages Class Members.  (Id. at ยถ 6.)  Under the
Settlement Agreement, and as further explained in the motion for preliminary approval, the following
expenses would be deducted from the Class Fund: attorneysโ fees of less than 30% of the Class Fund;

Counsel, and provided declarations.  (Id.; Litt Decl. ISO Final Approval Mot. ยถ 2.)
Such assertions do not support the awards sought by Plaintiffs.  However, the Court finds an
award of $2,500 to Pelaez, in addition to her damages award, and $500 to Nozzi, inclusive of his
damages, to be reasonable in light of their participation, and thus, grants awards to Named Plaintiffs in

D. Settlement Administration Award
Finally, Plaintiffs seek approval of settlement administration costs.  The Class Administrator has

Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, the Court finds that the Settlement Agreement is fundamentally fair,
adequate, and reasonable.  The Court therefore grants Plaintiffsโ Motion for Final Approval of
Settlement.  Injunctive Relief Class Members and Damages Class Members release those claims against

The Court also grants in part Plaintiffsโ Motion for Award of Attorneysโ Fees and awards
$2,801,776.94 in fees and $152,605.86 in costs to Class Counsel to be paid by Defendants. 
Additionally, the Court grants $2,500 to Pelaez as an incentive award and $500 to Nozzi as an incentive
award.  Furthermore, JNDโs costs of up to $60,000 are approved.  Each of these awards and costs are to
be paid from the Class Fund.
The Court orders Defendants to provide the Class Fund to the Class Administrator for
disbursement in accordance with the terms of the Settlement Agreement.  The Court further orders the
Class Administrator to pay all members of the Damages Class who have filed valid claims in accordance

SUMMARY**
Civil Rights
The panel reversed the district courtโs summary judgment
in favor of defendants, directed that summary judgment be
entered  in  favor  of  plaintiffs,  and  remanded  for  further
proceedings in a putative class action in which plaintiffs
alleged  that  defendants,  the  local  administrators  of  the
Section 8 Housing Choice Voucher Program, reduced the
amount  of  Section  8  beneficiariesโ  subsidies  without
providing adequate notice, in violation of federal and state
law.
The panel first noted that this Court had previously held
that plaintiffs have a property interest in Section 8 benefits to
which the procedural protections of the Due Process Clause
apply.  Nozzi v. Housing Authority of the City of Los Angeles,
425 F. Appโx 539 (9th Cir. 2011).  The panel held that the
Housing Authority failed to provide meaningful information
to Section 8 beneficiaries about a change to the programโs

4 NOZZI V. HACLA
OPINION
REINHARDT, Circuit Judge:
The Section 8 Housing Choice Voucher Program provides
rental assistance to the most vulnerable members of our
society.  For many, especially those in areas with a high cost
of living, the continuous receipt of these benefits is the only
means  through  which  Section  8  beneficiaries  and  their
families can obtain safe, affordable housing.  For those on a
fixed income or those living paycheck to paycheck, any
unexpected  decrease  in  the  subsidy  can  result  in
homelessness.    For  this  reason,  the  program  contains
procedural protections designed to ensure that beneficiaries
have at least a full year to plan for certain changes that may
decrease the beneficiaryโs subsidy and increase the rent that
they will have to pay.
 Plaintiffs are the putative class representatives of a group
of tenants who receive rent subsidies through the Section 8
Housing Choice Voucher Program.  They assert that the
Defendants, the local administrators of the Voucher Program,
reduced the amount of Section 8 beneficiariesโ subsidies
without providing adequate notice, in violation of federal and
state law.  We agree.  Accordingly, we reverse the grant of
summary judgment in favor of the defendants, direct that
summary judgment be entered in favor of the plaintiffs, and
remand for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 218   Filed 11/30/15   Page 5 of 48   Page ID #:1923
NOZZI V. HACLA 5
I.  STATUTORY AND REGULATORY BACKGROUND
A. Overview of the Section 8 Housing Choice Voucher
Program
In 1974, Congress created the Section 8 housing program
in order to โaid[] low-income families in obtaining a decent
place to liveโ and โpromot[e] economically mixed housing.โ 
Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, Pub. L.
93-383 ยง 201(a), 88 Stat. 633, 622โ66 (1974) (codified as
amended at 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f).  For over four decades, the
program  has  provided  rental  assistance  to  low-income,
elderly, and disabled families.  See generally Park Village
Apartment  Tenants  Assโn  v.  Mortimer  Howard  Trust,
636 F.3d 1150, 1152 (9th Cir. 2011).
The majority of federal housing assistance takes place
through  the  Housing  Choice  Voucher  Program,  which
subsidizes the cost of renting privately-owned housing units. 
42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o).  The Voucher Program is funded and
regulated by the federal Department of Housing and Urban
Development, and it is administered at the local level through
โpublic housing agencies.โ  24 C.F.R. ยง 982.1(a).
The  public  housing  agencies  determine  whether
individuals  are  eligible  to  participate  in  the  program. 
24 C.F.R. ยง 982.201.  When an individual is approved, the
public housing agency gives that person a voucher which
entitles him to search for qualifying privately-owned housing. 
24 C.F.R. ยง 982.302.  When a voucher-possessing individual
finds a qualifying unit, the unit owner and public housing
agency will negotiate and enter into a housing assistance
payment contract, which inter alia specifies the maximum
monthly rent that the unit owner may charge.  42 U.S.C.

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 218   Filed 11/30/15   Page 6 of 48   Page ID #:1924
6 NOZZI V. HACLA
ยง 1437f(c).  After that contract has been formed, the public
housing  agency will make subsidy payments to the unit
owner on behalf of the tenant.1
An extensive set of statutory provisions and regulations
governs the calculation of the subsidy that must be paid on
behalf of each tenant.  See 42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o); 24 C.F.R.
ยง 982.501 et seq.  To begin with, the Department of Housing
and Urban Development must set the fair market rent for
established  geographic  areas  across  the  United  States. 
24 C.F.R. ยง 982.503(a)(1).  The public housing agency must
use this fair market rent to create a local voucher โpayment
standardโ for each of the areas in its jurisdiction.  24 C.F.R.
ยง 982.503(b)(1)(I).  A payment standard is the maximum
subsidy payment that the housing agency will provide for
each type of apartment in the area.  Id.  It must generally be
set between 90 percent and 110 percent of the fair market rent
for the area.  24 C.F.R. ยง 982.503(b)(1)(i).2
All tenants are responsible for contributing 30% of their
monthly adjusted income or 10% of their gross monthly
   1 As the โbeneficiariesโ at issue in this opinion are those Section 8
recipients who have already secured and are currently leasing apartments
that are paid for, in part, by Section 8 subsidies, the terms โbeneficiaryโ
and โtenantโ are used interchangeably throughout the opinion.
   2 The public housing agency must request approval to establish a
payment standard outside of this range.  24 C.F.R. ยง 982.503(b)(2).  The
Department of Housing and Urban Development may approve such a
variance if the public housing agency meets one of the prescribed
exceptions.  See 24 C.F.R. ยง 982.503(c)โ(d).

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 218   Filed 11/30/15   Page 7 of 48   Page ID #:1925
NOZZI V. HACLA 7
income, whichever is greater.  42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(c)(2)(A).3 
Tenants  whose rental units  cost more than the payment
standard have a higher expected contribution.  Such tenants
must also pay any amount by which their rent exceeds the
established payment standard.  42 U.S.C. ยง 1437f(o)(2)(B).4 
In either case, the subsidy covers the balance of the rent.
B.  Procedures for Decreasing the Payment Standard
Practically,  the  formula  for  calculating  a  tenantโs
expected rent contribution means that a decision by the public
housing  agency  to  increase  the  payment  standard  will
generally yield larger subsidies.  By contrast, a decrease in
the payment standard will generally decrease subsidies and
may increase the rental contribution of a substantial number
of tenants.5
   3 This calculation must account for any welfare assistance tenants
receive that is specifically designated for housing costs.  42 U.S.C.
ยง 1437f(o)(2)(A)(iii).
   4 An example helps to illustrate this formula.  Abel and Beth both must
contribute 30% of their monthly adjusted income, for a total of $100 each. 
The payment standard for one-bedroom apartments in their area is $400. 
Abel rents a $400 apartment.  He must pay $100 towards his rent and will
receive the remaining $300 as a rent subsidy.  Beth rents a $500
apartment.  She must pay the $100 from her monthly adjusted income, but
must also pay the amount by which her $500 apartment exceeds the $400
payment standardโanother $100, for a total of $200.
   5 In the hypothetical above, if the public housing agency lowered the
payment standard for a one-bedroom apartment in the area from $400 to
$300, Abel, who is renting a $400 apartment, would now need to pay an
additional $100 for a total of $200.  Beth, who is renting a $500
apartment, would need to pay an additional $200, for a total of $300.  A
decrease in the payment standard would not cause an increase in rent
when: (1) the total rent for the unit is less than the lower payment

To  avoid  any  hardship  caused  by  this  change,  the
Department  of  Housing  and  Urban  Developmentโs
regulations are designed to ensure that beneficiaries have a
one-year  period  of  stable  benefits  in  which  to  plan  for
changes to the payment standard that may adversely affect
their subsidy amount and rent contribution.  Each year, the
public housing agency conducts annual examinations of each
beneficiary, usually on the anniversary of the beneficiaryโs
entry into the Section 8 program, to verify his continued
eligibility for benefits and to calculate his expected rent
contribution for the current year.  24 C.F.R. ยง 982.516. 
Alterations  to  a  tenantโs  benefits  may  occur  due  to
circumstantial changes, such as adjustments to the tenantโs
income, family composition, or cost to rent his apartment, but
the regulations limit the discretion of public housing agencies
to lower subsidies based on adjustments to the payment
standards.  If the public housing agency decides to lower the
payment standards, it must provide information about the
change to all beneficiaries at their annual reexaminations
following  the  decision,  and  must  further  advise  these
beneficiaries that the change will not go into effect until their
following  reexamination  one  year  later.    See  24  C.F.R.
ยง 982.505(c)(3).
 This requirement provides some measure of financial
stability for vulnerable Section 8 beneficiaries as it protects
against sudden decreases in subsidy at the whims of the
public  housing  agency.    Absent  any  changes  to  a
beneficiaryโs  circumstances,  he  can  be  assured  that  his
subsidy will renew with, at a minimum, the same terms as the
standard, (2) the tenantโs adjusted income has also decreased, or (3) the
public housing agency later raised the payment standard before the
decrease went into effect.

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 218   Filed 11/30/15   Page 9 of 48   Page ID #:1927
NOZZI V. HACLA 9
prior year unless he had previously been warned that the
public  housing  agency  has  taken  an  action  that  could
adversely  affect  his  subsidy.    The  regulations  cast  this
warning in terms of the public housing agencyโs duty to
provide  information  to  the  beneficiary  that  the  payment
standard has been decreased, to be effective at least a year
afterward.    Thus,  under  that  mandatory  procedure,  the
beneficiary necessarily has an expectation in an unaffected
one-year term of benefits following the warning in which to
plan for the changeโs potential adverse impact.
II.  FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
A. Implementation of the 2004 Payment Standard
Decrease
The  Housing  Authority  of  the  City  of  Los  Angeles
(โHousing Authorityโ) administers the Voucher Program for
that city.6  In 2004, the Department of Housing and Urban
Development  required  the  Housing  Authority  to  limit
spending in order to balance the Departmentโs 2004 budget. 
To meet the budget constraints, the Housing Authorityโs
Board of Commissioners reduced the payment standard from
110% of the 50th percentile of rents in Los Angeles County
to 100% of the 40th percentile of rents.  At the time, the
Board  estimated  that  โapproximately  45%  of  its
approximately 45,000 Section 8 tenants would be adversely
affected by the April 2004 decrease, and would have to pay
an average of $104 more in rent each month if they chose to
remain in their current units.  Of this number, nearly 5,000
   6 The plaintiffs in this case also sued the Executive Director of the
Housing Authority for the City of Los Angeles.  Throughout the opinion,
both defendants will be referred to as the โHousing Authority.โ

were elderly families, and nearly 4,500 were non-elderly,
disabled families.โ7
That year, the Housing Authority instructed its staff to
attach a copy of a flyer to each Section 8 beneficiariesโ
โnotice of review determinationโ or โRE-38,โ which is a form
sent annually to all Section 8 beneficiaries at the time of their

for benefits and sets forth their rent contribution and subsidy

โPAYMENT  STANDARDS  AND  TENANT-BASED

EFFECTIVE APRIL 2, 2004โ; (2) a table listing the new
payment standards; and (3) a statement that โRegardless of its

a minimum expected contribution of $50.  That change is not at issue in

location,  the  unitโs  rent  can  never  be  higher  than  the
comparable rents determined by the housing authority.โ8  For
simplicity, this will hereinafter be referred to as the โflyer.โ 
The attached RE-38 form showed the tenantโs subsidy and
rent contribution for the current year, a number that was
unaffected by the decreased payment standards.
Approximately one year later and only thirty days before
the changes to the payment standard were scheduled to be
implemented and to adversely affect the tenantsโ subsidies
and  rent  contributions,  the  Housing  Authority  sent  out
another  notice  of  review  determination.    This  particular
notice, which will hereinafter be referred to as the โfour-week
notice,โ set forth the tenantsโ subsidies and rents for the
upcoming year using the new, lowered payment standard. 
This was the first time that tenants were actually notified that
the change would affect them personally or that there would
be an increase to their rent contributions.
B. The Impacted Beneficiaries Sue
In  2007,  Plaintiffs  Michael Nozzi  and  Nidia  Palaez,
together with the Los Angeles Coalition to End Hunger and
Homelessness, filed an amended class action complaint on
behalf of affected Section 8 beneficiaries against the Housing
Authority and its Executive Director.9  They claimed that, as
   8 See Appendix A.
   9 Plaintiff Los Angeles Coalition to End Hunger and Homelessness is a
non-profit devoted to fighting the causes and effects of homelessness.  It
advocates  for  more  affordable  housing  on  behalf  of  low-income
individuals in Los Angeles.  Its membership includes people who receive
Section 8 benefits and who have been negatively affected by the 2004
decrease in the payment standard.

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 218   Filed 11/30/15   Page 12 of 48   Page ID #:1930
12 NOZZI V. HACLA
relevant  here,  the  Defendantsโ  failure  to  provide
comprehensible information to Section 8 beneficiaries about
the  payment  standard  change  and  its  effect  one  year in
advance of the changeโs implementation:  (1) violated the due
process  clauses  of  the  United  States  and  California
Constitutions,  (2)  violated  California  Government  Code
ยง 815.6, which governs liability for public entities that breach
mandatory duties, and (3) constituted negligence pursuant to
California Government Code ยง 815.2.
Plaintiff Michael Nozzi, a Section 8 beneficiary since
December 2003, is totally and permanently disabled under
Social Securityโs standards.  As a result of the 2004 change,
his expected rent contribution increased 48%โfrom $231 to
$342 per month.  Plaintiff Nidia Palaez, a beneficiary since
February 2004, is a single mother with a young daughter. 
She experienced a 177% increase in her portion of the rent as
a result of the 2004 change.  She alleges that this increase has
adversely affected her familyโs quality of life, that she has
had  difficulty  affording  suitable  school  clothes  for  her
daughter, and that she has had to divert money from her food
budget to cover her increased rent costs.
Both Nozzi and Palaez allege that they did not understand
that their Section 8 benefits would decrease and that their
own  rent  obligations  would  increase until  they  received
notices approximately one year after the flyer, four weeks
before the change in the payment standard adversely affected
their rent contribution.  Neither recalls receiving the original
flyer, and neither could comprehend it when it was later
shown to them.

C. The District Court Disposes of Plaintiffโs Claims
On November 26, 2007, the district court for the Central
District of California dismissed the plaintiffโs negligence
claim.  The court held that the plaintiffs failed to establish an
essential element for such claims against a public entity:  that
a statute imposed a mandatory duty on the entity.10
In early 2009, the parties filed cross-motions for summary
judgment on the remaining issues.  With respect to the due
process  claims,  the  Housing  Authority  argued  that  the
plaintiffs did not have a property interest protected by the due
process  clauses  of  the  United  States  or  California
Constitutions.
Furthermore, the Housing Authority asserted that, even if
the plaintiffs had a protected property interest, they received
sufficient process because the Housing Authority had sent the
flyer and โmade significant efforts to increase participantsโ
awareness of the 2004 VPS reduction through public hearings
and community outreach.โ  The Housing Authority supported
its position with (1) declarations from Housing Authority
employees summarily stating that all Section 8 beneficiaries
receive instructional training upon entry into the Section 8
program,  and  (2)  minutes  of  a  public  meeting  and  a
PowerPoint  presentation  used  at  the  meeting  discussing
changes to the Housing Authorityโs operation, during which
a brief discussion occurred regarding the payment standard
decrease.
   10 The district court also dismissed other claims that are not relevant to
this appeal.

14 NOZZI V. HACLA
In  response,  the  plaintiffs  argued  that  they  had  a
legitimate expectation in continued and stable Section 8
benefits.  They challenged the relevance of the Defendantsโ
purported  training  sessions  and  public  meetings  to  the
question whether the Housing Authority provided sufficient
notice  to  the  affected  beneficiaries.    Furthermore,  the
plaintiffs asserted, the only relevant question was whether the
flyer was reasonably comprehensible to the average recipient,
a  question  unaffected  by  the  Housing  Authorityโs  other
actions.
The district court granted summary judgment in favor of
the Housing Authority on the due process claims and the
remaining  state  statutory  claim,  an  alleged  violation  of
ยง 815.6.  According to the district court, the plaintiffs could
not have a protectable property interest in their Section 8

Next, it is apparent that the regulation was โdesigned to
protect against the kind of injuryโ the plaintiffs suffered. 
Haggis, 993 P.2d at 987โ88.  The regulation was created as
an equitable โsafeguardโ for tenants โagainst reductions in
subsidy,โ that would give Section 8 beneficiaries one year in
which to plan for adjustments to the payment standard that
could adversely affect their subsidy.  Section 8 Housing
Choice Voucher Program; Expansion of Payment Standard
Protection, 65 Fed. Reg. at 42508.  Here, because plaintiffs
were not given meaningful information about the change in
the  payment  standard  and  its  meaning  and  effect,  the
plaintiffs were deprived of the very one-year stable planning
period that the regulation was designed to protect.
Finally, the Housing Authority breached this mandatory
duty and this breach was the proximate cause of injury to the
plaintiffs.    As  described  earlier,  the  flyer  was  totally
incomprehensible to anyone without a relatively sophisticated
understanding  of  the  machinations  of  Section  8  subsidy
payments.  It did not provide the average recipient with any
meaningful information about the change or its potential
adverse impact.  As with the due process claims, the Housing
Authority argues that no injury could have occurred because
it had total discretion to decrease the payment standard.  Once
again,  the  Authority  misunderstands  the  nature  of  the
plaintiffsโ challenge.  The question here is not whether the
payment  standard  could  be  decreased,  but  whether  the
manner in which the Housing Authority implemented the

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 218   Filed 11/30/15   Page 43 of 48   Page ID #:1961
NOZZI V. HACLA 43
decrease breached its mandatory duty to provide advance
notice to plaintiffs of the intended action.  The answer is that
it did, and that plaintiffs, who experienced an unexpected and
dramatic increase in their rental obligations, suffered from
that breach.
What remains then, is the question whether the Housing
Authority โexercised reasonable diligence to discharge the
duty.โ  Cal. Govโt Code ยง 815.6.  As described in greater
detail  above,  there  are extreme  deficiencies in  the  flyer
provided to the plaintiffs.  The Housing Authority has had
two opportunities to come forward with evidence in support
of its motion for summary judgment and a further opportunity
to rebut the cross-motion for summary judgment brought by
the plaintiffs in Nozzi I.  Despite this, it has fallen far short of
producing evidence sufficient to raise a genuine issue of fact
as  to  whether  it  made  reasonable  efforts  to  provide
meaningful information to the plaintiffs about the payment
standard change and its adverse effect upon them.
 The Housing Authority initially took the position that it
was โimpossibleโ to draft a different, more comprehensible
notice,  but  that  position  is  plainly  contradicted  by  the
undisputed evidence.  The Housing Authority was clearly
capable of explaining the meaning and effect of the payment
standard.  It provided a comprehensible notice to Voucher
Program beneficiaries who had not yet found a unit to rent. 
Indeed, it provided an even more thorough explanation of the
meaning and effect of the change to the Mayor, members of
the Los Angeles City Council, and California congressmen.
The Housing Authority produced evidence, in the form of
a  declaration  by  the  individual  who  wrote  the  flyer,
purportedly showing that he exercised reasonable efforts. 

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 218   Filed 11/30/15   Page 44 of 48   Page ID #:1962
44 NOZZI V. HACLA
Even construing this declaration in the light most favorable
to the defendants, however, it is insufficient to raise a genuine
issue of fact as to whether the Housing Authority exercised
reasonable  efforts  to  comply  with  the  regulation.    The
declaration states that the employee drafts all of his notices in
language that can be understood by a person with an eighth
grade education.  This is a conclusion that is belied by the
evidence.  The flyer unquestionably does not explain the
meaning and effect of the change in the payment standard in
any terms at all, let alone in terms that can be understood by
a person with an eighth grade education.  The employee
admittedly simply took the flyerโs language directly from the
regulation, and the Housing Authority did not offer any
evidence that he took any steps to ensure that the language
would provide any meaningful information about the change
that would advise the average recipient of its meaning or
effect.  Nor did the Housing Authority offer any evidence
suggesting  that  the  employee  considered  alternatives  to
merely parroting the regulation, such as, inter alia, defining
payment standardโas did the letters sent to house-hunting
Section 8 beneficiaries and to the public officials.
Thus,  as  with  the  due  process  claims,  the  Housing
Authority had ample opportunity to develop facts to support
its defense against the state law claims, but failed to do so. 
Accordingly, we reverse the judgment of the district court and
remand with instructions to grant summary judgment in favor
of the plaintiffs on the merits of this statutory claim.
B. California Government Code ยง 815.2
Under California Government Code ยง 815.2, a public
entity is โvicariously liable for its employeesโ [non-immune]
negligent  acts  or  omissions  within  the  scope  of

Case 2:07-cv-00380-PA-FFM   Document 218   Filed 11/30/15   Page 45 of 48   Page ID #:1963
NOZZI V. HACLA 45
employment[.]โ    Eastburn  v.  Regional  Fire  Protection
Authority, 80 P.3d 656, 658 (Cal. 2003).  The Housing
Authority asserts, and the plaintiffs do not dispute, that
plaintiffs  theory  of  negligence  is  โessentially
interchangeableโ with its ยง 815.6 claim discussed in Section
V.A above.  Indeed, the elements of a vicarious liability claim
against a public entity in California are โvirtually identicalโ
to the elements of a ยง 815.6 claim.  Alejo v. City of Alhambra,
89 Cal. Rptr. 2d 768, 771 & n.3 (Ct. App. 1999); see also San
Mateo Union High School District v. Cnty. of San Mateo,
152 Cal. Rptr. 3d 530, 542โ544 (Ct. App. 2013).  The above
discussion of the plaintiffsโ ยง 815.6 claim, therefore, applies
equally to their vicarious liability claim and they are entitled
to summary judgment on the merits of this claim as well.
VI.    REASSIGNMENT
Plaintiffs have requested that we use our supervisory
power to reassign this case to a different district judge on
remand.  We reassign a case to a different district judge in
โunusual circumstances.โ  Krechman v. County of Riverside,
723 F.3d 1104, 1111 (9th Cir. 2013).  To determine whether
such reassignment is appropriate we look to three factors: 
(1) whether the original judge could โreasonably be expected
upon remand to have substantial difficulty in putting out of
his  or  her  mind  previously-expressed  views  or  findings
determined to be erroneous or based on evidence that must be
rejected,โ (2) whether reassignment is advisable to preserve
the appearance of justice, and (3) whether reassignment
would โentail waste and duplication out of proportion to any
gain  in  preserving  the  appearance  of  fairness.โ    Id.  at
1111โ12.

46 NOZZI V. HACLA
On remand from Nozzi I, the district judge made a number
of statements indicating his strong disagreement with this
Courtโs holding in Nozzi I.  Then, before ruling in favor of the
Housing Authority for the second time, the judge stated,
โWhen you do argue this in the Ninth Circuit, donโt make just
that argument, because if you do . . . weโll be back here again,
and Iโll be tearing out my hair and saying I donโt understand
why this happened the way it did.  In fact, let me just indicate
that if this case gets reversed, I want it to be like Judge
Wright or Judge Real.  I want it to go to some other district
court judge, because I have spent a lot of time on this case. 
. . . I pretty much have done all I can.โ
The district judgeโs statements constitute a โrare and
extraordinary  circumstance[]โ  justifying  reassignment. 
Krechman, 723 F.3d at 1112.  The judge repeatedly made
clear that he would have substantial difficulty setting aside
his previous views of the case.  Under these circumstances,
remand is not only โadvisable,โ Krechman, 723 F.3d at 1111,
but essential in order to preserve the appearance of justice. 
Accordingly,  we  need  not  consider  the  third  factor. 
Krechman, 723 F.3d at 1102 (โThe first two factors are
equally important and a finding of either is sufficient to
support reassignment on remand.โ).  Regardless whether
duplication of effort would be involved, we have no choice
but to send the case to a judge whose designation would
appear to be consistent with the interests of justice.28  Lastly,
we hold that this case must be reassigned to a district judge
   28 Although it does not affect our decision, we note that reassignment
will not entail more than minimal duplication as there is little, if any,
overlap between issues to be resolved on remand and the issues previously
considered by the district court.

NOZZI V. HACLA 47
other than one of the two judges named by Judge Wu in order
to โpreserve the appearance of justice.โ  Id.
VII.  CONCLUSION
In sum, the district court erred by granting summary
judgment to the Housing Authority.  There is no genuine
dispute of fact as to whether the Housing Authority failed to
provide meaningful information to Section 8 beneficiaries
about the change to the payment standard and the effect of
that  change  upon  the  beneficiaries  and  their  property
interests.  That failure violated both the requirements of the
Voucher  Program  regulations  and  the  requirements  of
procedural due process.  It also resulted in a violation of two
state statutes which require public entities to take reasonable
efforts to comply with the mandatory duties established by
federal regulations.  Accordingly, we reverse and remand
with instructions for the district court to enter summary
judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on the merits of the federal
and state law claims at issue on this appeal.  In order to
preserve  the  appearance  of  justice,  we  order  the  case
reassigned to a different district judgeโa judge other than the
two identified by the current district judge who himself has
declined to hear the case further.  On remand, further factual
development  may  be  needed  to  determine  the  size  and
validity of plaintiffsโ class and to determine the appropriate
remedy.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.

the foregoing reasons, the Court finds that the Settlement Agreement is fundamentally
fair, adequate, and reasonable. The Court therefore grants Plaintiffs' Motion for Final
Approval of Settlement. Injunctive Relief Class Members and Damages Class
Members release those claims against Defendants as set forth in the Settlement
Agreement, except as to monetary damages for those Damages Class Members who
timely opted out. The Court reaffirms its approval of Barrett S. Litt, Anne Richardson,
and Stephanie Carroll as Class Counsel and JND as Class Administrator. The Court
also grants in part Plaintiffs' Motion for Award of Attorneys' Fees and awards
$2,801,776.94 in fees and $152,605.86 in costs to Class Counsel to be paid by
Defendants. Additionally, the Court grants $2,500 to Pelaez as an incentive award and
$500 to Nozzi as an incentive award. Furthermore, JND's costs of up to $60,000 are
approved. Each of these awards and costs are to be paid from the Class Fund. (See
document for further details) (mrgo) (Entered: 02/15/2018)
02/15/2018 332  JUDGMENT by Judge Percy Anderson, Related to: Order on Motion for Attorney
Fees, 331 . IT IS HEREBY ORDERED, ADJUDGED, AND DECREED that: 1. All
terms herein shall have the same meaning as the terms defined in the Settlement
Agreement, unless otherwise specifically provided herein. (See document for details)
